nodes.text: Changing which colleges students attend can substantially reduce parental-income segregation across colleges and increase intergenerational mobility in the United States, even without changing colleges' educational programs

We construct a near-complete administrative data set linking deidentified federal tax records, Department of Education records (1098-T and Pell/NSLDS), College Board SAT and ACT data to measure (i) parents' household incomes, (ii) students' college attendance, (iii) students' adult earnings, and (iv) test scores and race for nearly all U.S. college students (1999–2013)

Parental income segregation across colleges is very high—comparable to segregation across childhood neighborhoods—and concentrated at elite colleges: Ivy-Plus colleges enroll many more top-income students than bottom-income students

Evidence: Ivy-Plus colleges (8 Ivies + Duke, MIT, Stanford, Chicago) have 14.5% of students from top 1% and only 3.8% from bottom quintile; children from top 1% are 77 times more likely to attend Ivy-Plus than bottom-quintile children; two-thirds of variation in bottom-quintile shares is within selectivity tiers

Within a given college, differences in adult earnings between students from low- versus high-income parents are much smaller than the nationwide parent-child earnings association, implying much of national persistence is due to between-college sorting

Evidence: National rank-rank slope is about 0.29 (child rank on parent rank); including college fixed effects reduces slope to 0.139; among college-goers with college fixed effects slope falls to ~0.10; within elite colleges slope ~0.065 — within-college gradients are roughly one-third to one-fifth of national gradient

Some colleges—notably several mid-tier public institutions—combine large shares of low-income students with relatively strong adult earnings outcomes for those students, producing high upward-mobility rates

Evidence: Top bottom-to-top-quintile mobility-rate colleges include Cal State LA, SUNY Stony Brook, several CUNY campuses, UT-Pan American and community colleges; mobility rate = fraction low-income × fraction of those who reach top quintile (examples: Cal State LA mobility ~9.9%)

We simulate counterfactual reallocations of students to colleges using observed SAT/ACT scores, race, and geography: (a) an income-neutral allocation that randomizes college slots conditional on test score, race, and state; and (b) need-affirmative allocations that add a test-score advantage (e.g., +160 SAT points for bottom quintile) to low- and middle-income students; missing test scores are imputed and validated

Result from income-neutral allocation: holding racial and geographic composition and the distribution of test scores fixed, income-neutral allocation would substantially reduce segregation overall (closing ~64% of the gap to full integration among current college-goers) and increase middle-class representation at Ivy-Plus, but would only modestly raise bottom-quintile shares at Ivy-Plus (e.g., Ivy-Plus bottom share rises from 3.8% to 4.4%)

Result from need-affirmative allocation (e.g., +160 SAT points to bottom quintile, scaled for other quintiles): this counterfactual would essentially eliminate differences in parental income distributions across college selectivity tiers and substantially increase representation of low- and middle-income students at selective colleges

Assumption used for mobility simulations: baseline assumes 80% of observed differences in students' earnings across colleges conditional on SAT/ACT, race, and parental income are causal (colleges' value-added), with remaining 20% due to selection; robustness checks consider a range from 0% to 100%

Simulated mobility impacts under the 80%-causal assumption: income-neutral allocations reduce intergenerational persistence among college students by about 15%; need-affirmative allocations reduce it by about 25% (larger reductions for top-1% upper-tail mobility under need-affirmative)

Limitations and caveats: results sensitive to the causal-share assumption and ignore potential equilibrium changes in colleges' value-added (peer effects, institutional responses); counterfactuals hold college seats fixed and preserve current college attendance margins (do not change who attends college)

Conclusion: feasible changes in how students are allocated to colleges—through application, admission, or matriculation policies—could substantially reduce income segregation across colleges and materially increase intergenerational mobility even without changing college educational programs, though outcomes depend on colleges' causal impacts and implementation details
